text.p: This is how major world bond markets were trading in late European business on Friday.

GERMANY - Bund futures ended the day just shy of intraday highs, boosted by the news that U.S. Jan Chicago purchasing managers index fell to 55.9 from 57.1. The March Bund future on the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange (LIFFE) was trading at 101.74, up 0.52 from Thursday's settlement price.

BRITAIN - Gilts closed higher, spurred on in the afternoon by strong U.S Treasuries after a tame US price deflator took the sting out of a strong jump in fourth quarter GDP. The March long gilt future on LIFFE was trading at 110-30/32, up 24/32 from Thursday's settlement price.

FRANCE - Long awaited U.S. economic data sent conflicting signals to bond markets, leaving French bonds slightly lower with traders cautious ahead of monetary policy meetings in both German and United States next week. The March bond future on the MATIF in Paris settled at 130.48, down 0.06 from Thursday's settlement price.

ITALY - Debt markets managed to hold on to positive ground with the November 2006 cash Btp notching up better gains than the March LIFFE future. The most traded July 2006 Btp however was much in line with the future, ending eight basis points up at 109.98. The future was also eight basis points stronger at 130.55 having tracked the U.S. market. The March bond future on LIFFE was trading at 130.53, up 0.06 from Thursday's settlement price.

UNITED STATES - U.S. Treasuries were sharply higher in moderate midday trading as a combination of friendly pieces of economic data prompted dealers and money managers to cover some short positions. The March Treasury bond future on the Chicago Board of Trade was trading at 111-12/32, up 26/32 from Thursday's settlement price. The long bond was quoted to yield 6.81 percent.

JAPAN - The key March 10-year Japanese government bond futures contract closed firmer as persistent investor buying in cash bonds forced those who had gone short to cover their positions. In after hours trading the March future on LIFFE was trading at 126.35, up 0.20 from Thursday's settlement price on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

EUROBONDS - Following a very active start to the year, primary market supply simmered down with expectations of a subdued start to February amid cautiousness ahead of next week's U.S. FOMC meeting.The highlight of the day was the launch of the EIB's 1.0 billion Ecu-into-Euro April 2004 bond which performed well. In the emerging market sector, investors presentations for Panama, the Ivory Coast and Croatia hit London.
